question: Which of the following is the typical peak period of beta-hCG levels during pregnancy?

A deceased young woman was brought in for an autopsy. Examination revealed that she was pregnant and had sustained severe injuries in the pelvic region. Upon inquiry, her mother stated that the woman had attempted a criminally induced abortion, during which she died within minutes. Which of the following is the most probable cause of death in this patient?
According to Pakistani law, abortion is justified only under which of the following conditions?

answers.option: If a woman has a family
To save the life of the mother
If it is performed by a trained doctor
In case of an unmarried woman

question: You are asked to examine a female suspected of sexual assault. Examination findings reveal a deflorated female. What does defloration mean?
You are asked to examine a female suspected of sexual assault. Examination findings reveal a ruptured hymen. What is the most common site of rupture of the hymen in a virgin?
Upon taking a detailed history from an offender, it is revealed that he frequently has intercourse with animals. What is this sexual perversion termed as?
Which of the following refers to a type of sexual perversion in which the person gets sexual gratification by inflicting pain on their partner?
Which one of the following is the absolute contraindication of intravenous pyelography (IVP)?
Ultrasound of the kidneys is the key radiologic modality in patients with renal failure as it is useful in the assessment of which of the following aspects?

A 50-year old male patient with diabetes and hypertension presents to the emergency department with complaints of decreased appetite, easy fatigability, and progressive shortness of breath over the last 4-5 months. On examination, his BP was 165/90 mmHg, pulse 85/min, and respiratory rate 26/min. He appears pale, with periorbital puffiness and bilateral pedal edema. Laboratory results show Hb: 8.0 g/dL, normal TLC and platelets, BUN: 60, serum creatinine: 3.2 mg/dL, and elevated potassium. An old report from around 8 months ago shows similar levels of deranged renal parameters. What is the best possible diagnosis?

During a clinical interview, the doctor asked the patient, "What were your feelings when you were talking about a fractured arm, as you mentioned that you were a physical trainer and could easily lift ten-kilogram weights ten times?" Asking about emotions and feelings attached to various symptoms and problems is an example of which of the following?

A 45-year-old male patient has recently been diagnosed with advanced-stage stomach cancer. The doctor disclosed this news to the family and did not talk about it to the patient, as per their request. The patient later learned about it from other staff and went into shock and depression subsequently. Which of the following disclosure model, the doctor should most likely to be followed in this case?

A 60-year-old man seeks medical attention because of recurrent urinary tract infections. The patient also reports a history of increasing difficulty in urination with decreased flow, straining, and hesitancy over the last several months. A prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is mildly elevated, and a prostate biopsy proves benign. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?

A 55-year-old man presents with fever and pain in the perineal region. Upon further questioning, he also complains of frequency, urgency, dysuria, and a decreased urinary stream. On physical examination, his abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. Digital rectal examination demonstrates exquisite tenderness on the anterior aspect. Laboratory examination reveals leukocytosis, and findings on urinalysis are consistent with a bacterial infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency room with renal colic. His vital signs are normal, and a urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. A radiograph reveals a 1.5 cm stone. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

answers.option: Open surgery to remove the stone

question: A 32-year-old man presents with an asymptomatic mass in his right testicle. On ultrasound, the mass is solid, and on examination, the mass cannot be trans-illuminated. Which of the following is the most accurate method in obtaining a diagnosis of testicular cancer?

answers.option: Excisional biopsy of the testicular mass through a scrotal incision
Percutaneous biopsy of the testicular mass
Incisional biopsy of the testicular mass through a scrotal incision
Serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin

question: Which of the following structures is not developed from the ureteric bud?
Which is the most anterior structure passing through the hilum of the kidney?

A researcher collects data on the systolic blood pressure of 100 hypertensive patients and wants to summarize the data. Which graphical method is most appropriate for displaying the frequency distribution of this continuous variable?
A study was conducted to compare the mean hemoglobin levels between male and female medical students. Which statistical test would be most appropriate?

A chi-square test is performed to assess the association between smoking status (smoker/non-smoker) and the presence of hypertension (yes/no). The p-value obtained is 0.03. What is the correct interpretation?

answers.option: Smoking status has no association with hypertension.
There is a statistically significant association between smoking status and hypertension.
A t-test should be used instead of the chi-square test.
The test cannot be interpreted because the p-value is greater than 0.05.
There is insufficient evidence to suggest an association between smoking status and hypertension.

question: A 5-year-old boy has had dark urine and facial swelling for three days. He had a throat infection one week ago. On examination, he is hypertensive and edematous. Urine dipstick reveals red blood cells and casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized body swelling and decreased urine output. His lab investigations show a serum albumin of 2.5 g/dl, serum creatinine of 0.5 mg/dl , a serum cholesterol of 250 mg/dl and urine dipstick reveals 3+ proteinuria, no RBC or RBC casts. Based on the clinical and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old male, known to have diabetes mellitus and using alcohol occasionally, presented with loose stools (watery in consistency) for 3 days. He has been passing around 10-12 episodes every day. On examination, he was dehydrated and passing only 200 mL of urine in 24 hours. Initial investigations showed an Hb of14.8 g/dL, TLC of 11.2 x 10²/L, platelet count of 324 x 10³/L of creatinine of 4.2 mg/dL, K+ of9.4 mEq/L, HCO₃ of 18 mEq/L and urea of 94 mg/dL. Among the above-mentioned laboratory parameters, which of the following is a highly indicative marker for hemodialysis?
A study aims to predict the fasting blood sugar levels (mg/dL) based on BMI (kg/m²) among adults. Which statistical method is most appropriate?
Which of the following is the most important assumption of logistic regression?

answers.option: There should be no multicollinearity among the independent variables.
The relationship between variables is non-linear.
The outcome variable must be binary
The independent variables are normally distributed.

question: A 50-year-old man has frequent episodes of renal colic with calcium-containing renal stones. Workup indicates that he has a defect in proximal tubular calcium reabsorption, resulting in high concentrations of calcium salts in the tubular urine. Which of the following is the most useful diuretic agent in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones?

A 56-year-old woman recently diagnosed with congestive heart failure started a therapy that included furosemide. Acetazolamide was also added to counteract the potential metabolic alkalosis induced by furosemide. Which of the following molecular actions most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of acetazolamide in this patient?

answers.option: Stimulation of carbonic acid formation inside the tubular cells
Stimulation of H+ reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase in the tubular lumen
Inhibition of Na+ reabsorption in the early distal tubule
Stimulation of bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule

question: A 63-year-old man with a long history of heart failure was admitted to the hospital because of severe dyspnea and edema in the legs, thighs, and lower abdominal wall. The physician decided to start furosemide. Which of the following molecular actions most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of furosemide in this patient?

answers.option: Blockade of Na+/Cl-symport in the early distal tubule
Blockade of Na+ reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Blockade of Na+/K+/2Cl-symport in the Henle's loop
Inhibition of aldosterone actions in the collecting tubule
Blockade of Na+ channels in the collecting tubule

question: A 24-year-old female presents with decreased urination and hematuria for 2 days. She has been unwell for the past 15 days with severe sore throat and high-grade fever with chills. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and temperature is 100°F. Systemic and general physical examinations were unremarkable. Which of the following urinary casts is most specific for her illness?

A 50-year-old male is admitted to the medical ward with a history of abdominal distention and pedal edema. He is diagnosed with chronic liver disease (Cirrhosis). Laboratory investigations show the following: CBC: Hb 10 g/dL, WBC 3 x 10³/mm³, Platelets 105 x 10³/mm³ Serum Albumin: 2.7 g/dL Prothrombin time: 18 sec (Control: 11-14 sec) Serum Sodium: 122 mEq/L Serum Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L Serum Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL What is the cause of hyponatremia in this patient based on his history and physical examination?

A 60-year-old male, a known diabetic for 8 years and taking oral hypoglycemic drugs, is admitted to the medical ICU with an altered level of consciousness. There is no history of fever, and there are no signs of meningeal irritation. Investigations reveal the following: CBC: Hb 11 g/dL, WBC 5 x 10³/mm³, Platelets 162 x 10³/mm³ RBS: 590 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL Serum Sodium: 168 mg/dL Serum Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L Which of the following should not be given to this patient at this time to correct metabolic and electrolyte problems?

A 55-year-old male patient with a history of controlled diabetes mellitus presents with chills, high-grade fever, and pain and tenderness over the kidneys. Ultrasound shows right-sided hydronephrosis and hydroureter. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

answers.option: Can be managed as outpatient on oral antibiotics
Should be admitted, given I/V antibiotics, and drainage by percutaneous nephrostomy
Should be given I/V antibiotics empirically
Should be given I/V fluids and cranberry juice

question: A 25-year-old pregnant female is advised a urine analysis and urine culture at 12 weeks of gestation. Regarding asymptomatic bacteriuria, which of the following is correct?

answers.option: Up to 10 organisms/ml is considered diagnostic
Normal urine culture does not exclude asymptomatic bacteriuria
Any number of organisms is regarded as significant
More than 10 organisms/ml is regarded as significant
More than 10^5 organisms/ml is regarded as significant

question: A 49-year-old male known diabetic, went for a follow-up renal check-up and was found to have an eGFR of 36 ml/min/1.73m². He was carrying reports from 4 months ago, which showed urea levels of 78mg/dl, serum creatinine of 2.3mg/dl, eGFR of 38ml/ml/min/1.73m² and albumin:creatinine ratio of 300mg/g. What will be the stage of his disease?

If the average hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries is 50 mmHg, the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman's space is 12 mmHg, the average colloid osmotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries is 30 mmHg, and there is no protein in the glomerular ultrafiltrate. Which of the following values is the net pressure driving glomerular filtration?

A 35-year-old male presents with right lumbar pain, difficulty in micturition, and increased frequency of urine. X-ray reveals a renal stone in the right ureter, obstructing the urinary flow. Which of the following pressures on the glomerular capillary membrane will be increased in this condition?

A 70-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the groin, hematuria, and anuria. Ultrasound shows unilateral obstruction with dilated pelvis and calyces. The physician diagnoses him with hydronephrosis. What is the site of obstruction?
A 66-year-old male presents with the complaint of complete anuria and pain in the groin region. X-ray shows a stone below the level of the ureters. What would be the diagnosis?

answers.option: Hydronephrosis due to unilateral partial obstruction
Hydronephrosis due to bilateral partial obstruction
Hydronephrosis due to impaired vesicoureteral reflux
Hydronephrosis due to unilateral complete obstruction
Hydronephrosis due to bilateral complete obstruction

question: A 40-year-old female presents with severe abdominal pain, radiating to her back. CT scan shows bilateral ureterolithiasis. Which one of the following is appropriate regarding the stones?

A 32-year-old male patient presents with complaints of bilateral episodic lumbar pain for 6 months. Urine D/R shows numerous pus cells and the pH of urine is 8.5. Urine culture reports growth of staphylococci. X-ray reveals large radiolucent bilateral stones. What would be the diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman complains of dysuria, polyuria, and chronic lower back pain. Urine D/R shows numerous pus cells with a pH of 4. A KUB radiograph shows small calcifications in the left kidney. What is the most likely composition of these calcifications?

A 65-year-old male presents with dysuria, frequency, and urgency. He has a history of a right renal transplant. Urine culture shows growth of E. coli. The X-ray shows a contracted kidney with blunting and deformity of the calyces. What would be the diagnosis?
Regarding tubulointerstitial nephritis, which of the following statements is correct?
Regarding secondary tubulointerstitial nephritis (TIN), which of the following statements is incorrect?

answers.option: Vascular diseases can lead to secondary TIN
Metabolic diseases can lead to secondary TIN
Glomerular abnormalities may also present in advanced stages of these diseases
Vascular diseases cannot lead to secondary TIN
Cystic diseases of the kidney can lead to secondary TIN

question: Regarding causes of tubulointerstitial nephritis, which of the following statements is incorrect?

answers.option: It can be caused by parasites
It can be caused by bacterial pyelonephritis
It can be caused by urinary tract obstruction
It can be caused by viruses
Renal transplant rejection cannot lead to tubulointerstitial nephritis

question: Regarding histological features of chronic pyelonephritis, all statements are true except for which of the following?

answers.option: Interstitial inflammation comprising of PMN and eosinophils
Interstitial inflammatory infiltrate comprising of mononuclear leukocytes

question: Which of the following is not associated with acute pyelonephritis?

answers.option: Male gender of more than 40 years
